utterances: And did you get to rename it Iron Maven?
That was a thing of ownership, that there was an actual roller derby girl.
I don't think she wanted to give up her name…
…or she don't want it in the movie.
And Iron Maven, the actual Iron Maven is one of the - plays one of the Manson sisters in the movie.
She's skating in the movie, and she was so generous to let us use her name, because it's a pretty killer name.
Angela, thanks very much for the call.
I got to tell you, come to the live show.
Yeah, go on Twitter or Facebook, all that jazz, and get those tour dates.
Let's see if we can go next to - this is Patrick, Patrick in Fort Collins, Colorado.
Hey, how is it going, Juliette?
I just thought The Licks were…
You really - you give me nightmares after I go through this (unintelligible).
I'll take it that's a compliment, yeah.
Oh, it's just power, just pure power.
Anyone who hasn't seen Juliette, go.
You are sadly mistaken if you don't.
But I wanted to ask you something.
I know this is, you know, about roles, you know, from about just, sort of, 20 years ago.
But how was it that you were able to play such naive, innocent characters amongst just pure, unadulterated madness in films like ""Cape Fear"" and ""Kalifornia""?
And I've always wondered how it is that you were just able to put this - I don't know.
It was like you were just this strange angel amongst devils with such…
Can I - if you see that as a lyric later, are you going to sue me?
This is the duality that's sort of driven me insane in my young life.
My point is, I don't know, but I sort of, as of late, and especially on this new record ""Terra Incognita,"" I embrace that duality, but that I'm as vulnerable as I am cynical and roaring.
Or I'm as, you know, disillusioned as I am hopeful.
And it's sort of these juxtaposition of emotions, I think, that we all feel, and I'm just able to tap into the very - I'm really - I don't know.
I don't know why, but this has sort of been my nature as a kid.
Just - I deal with primal energies and that's, you know, I don't tend to go middle of the road with emotion or - and stuff.
So - but I've been fortunate to work on really interesting movies that were high-stakes dramas and very rich with emotions.
But thank you for your question.
And, Patrick, thank you for your phone call.
And your vocal chops on ""Strange Days"" were just as excellent.
And, yeah, I'll be - I would be a groupie, but unfortunately, I'm a musician myself so I got to have standards, too.
We're playing Boulder, Colorado actually, I think, in like, five days.
I don't know if that's far from you in Colorado.
Oh, no, no, no. That's totally not far from me at all.
We're talking with actress Juliette Lewis, one of the stars of Drew Barrymore's directorial debut, ""Whip It,"" which opens this weekend.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.
And you and your director share more than a few traits.
You both acted a lot as kids.
No, I thought you we're going to say, and you both had a wild, you know, past and stuff like that.
And what was funny is we never really knew each other early on, so I never really met Drew until this movie, you know, and I met her in her office.
I'm really knocked out by her and the path that she's forged, you know?
Before this movie, she's produced, like, eight films…
…and really has great taste in cinema.
So it was neat to meet with her and be directed by her.
Let's go next to Malory(ph), Malory with us from Wichita.
I have been skating with the ICT Rollers Girls in Wichita for the last - about four years now.
And I just wanted to say that I was impressed with how ""Whip It"" highlighted the diverse range of women involved in the sport and kind of the sisterhood that goes along with that.
